episodeTitle: The Battle is Over! Koza Raises the White Flag!
titleJapanese: 戦いは終わった！コーザが掲げた白い旗
titleRomanized: Tatakai wa owatta! Kōza ga ageta shiroi hata
description: The Tsumegeri Guards sacrifice themselves using Hero Water to fight Crocodile, but fail. Chaka transforms into his jackal form to attack Crocodile but is defeated. Vivi reveals the truth to Koza, who raises white flags to stop the rebellion, but is shot by Baroque Works agents disguised as royal soldiers.

events.title: Tsumegeri Guards Drink Hero Water
events.description: The four elite Tsumegeri Guards (Hyota, Brahm, Arrow, and Barrel) consume the forbidden Hero Water, granting them superhuman strength for five minutes but ensuring their death. They charge at Crocodile to protect King Cobra and Alabasta.
events.significance: Demonstrates the desperate sacrifice of Alabasta's loyal warriors and introduces Hero Water as a last-resort power enhancement with fatal consequences.

events.title: Death of the Tsumegeri Guards
events.description: After their attack fails against Crocodile's sand body, the five-minute effect of Hero Water expires. All four Tsumegeri Guards collapse and die simultaneously from the poison, sacrificing their lives in vain as Crocodile refused to even fight them seriously.
events.significance: A tragic moment showing the futility of their noble sacrifice against a Logia user without knowing his weakness. Demonstrates Crocodile's ruthlessness and tactical superiority.

quotes.text: I won't bother to fight them since they're going to die anyway.
quotes.speaker: Crocodile
quotes.context: Crocodile's cold response to the guards' sacrifice

events.title: Chaka's Jackal Transformation
events.description: Enraged by the deaths of the Tsumegeri Guards and Crocodile's mockery, Chaka reveals his Devil Fruit power, the Inu Inu no Mi Model: Jackal, transforming into a human-jackal hybrid. He attacks Crocodile using his technique Howling Fangs while wielding his sword.
events.significance: First demonstration of Chaka's Devil Fruit abilities. Establishes him as one of Alabasta's two guardian deities (along with Pell). Shows another futile attack against Crocodile's Logia powers.

events.title: Crocodile Defeats Chaka
events.description: Chaka's attacks prove ineffective against Crocodile's sand body. Crocodile easily defeats Chaka, leaving him bloodied and unconscious on the palace grounds. Vivi cries out in horror as another of Alabasta's protectors falls.
events.significance: Further demonstrates Crocodile's overwhelming power and the hopelessness of Alabasta's defenders without knowledge of his weakness to water.

events.title: Crocodile Reveals His Scheme to Koza
events.description: Koza arrives at the palace and witnesses Crocodile's true nature. Vivi reveals to Koza that Crocodile, the supposed hero of Alabasta, is actually the mastermind behind the drought, the rebellion, and all of Alabasta's suffering. Crocodile boasts about manipulating both the rebels and the royal army.
events.significance: Critical revelation that exposes Operation Utopia to one of the key players. Koza finally learns the truth about who is really responsible for Alabasta's civil war.

events.title: Koza Raises the White Flag
events.description: After learning the truth from Vivi and Chaka's warning about the bomb, Koza and the royal army raise white flags of surrender to stop the rebellion. They proclaim peace to the approaching rebel forces, attempting to end the fighting before the bomb destroys everyone.
events.significance: Koza's desperate attempt to save both armies from Crocodile's bomb plot. A pivotal moment where peace seems within reach.

events.title: Koza Shot by Baroque Works Agents
events.description: As Koza attempts to tell the rebels the conflict is over, he is suddenly shot multiple times from behind by Baroque Works operatives disguised as royal soldiers. The rebels misinterpret this as royal treachery and the violence escalates, destroying any hope for peaceful resolution.
events.significance: Crocodile's sabotage ensures the war continues despite Koza's sacrifice. A tragic moment that shows how deep Baroque Works' infiltration goes and how Crocodile has planned for every contingency.

events.title: Bomb Timer Revealed - 25 Minutes Remaining
events.description: The episode reveals that Crocodile's massive bomb in the palace square has 25 minutes remaining before detonation. The bomb has a five-kilometer blast radius and is designed to kill everyone in the battlefield when the fighting reaches its climax.
events.significance: Establishes the ticking clock tension for the climax of the Arabasta arc. The bomb represents Crocodile's final insurance that his plan will succeed regardless of individual battles.

events.title: Straw Hats Regroup
events.description: Sanji, Usopp, and Chopper regroup together with Matsuge the camel after their individual battles. They discuss the situation and prepare to head toward the palace to help stop the bomb.
events.significance: Shows the Straw Hats regrouping as they move toward the final confrontations of the Arabasta arc.

events.title: Pandaman Cameo
events.description: Pandaman, the series' recurring Easter egg character, makes a brief appearance around the 3:30 mark among the palace guards during the battle scenes.
events.significance: Continues the long-running tradition of Pandaman cameos throughout the One Piece series.

quotes.text: I won't bother to fight them since they're going to die anyway.
quotes.speaker: Crocodile
quotes.context: Crocodile's cold response to the Tsumegeri Guards' sacrifice

themes.description: The Tsumegeri Guards and Chaka make noble sacrifices to protect their kingdom, but their efforts are rendered futile by Crocodile's overwhelming Logia powers and their lack of knowledge about his weaknesses.
themes.symbolism: The Hero Water represents the ultimate sacrifice - trading life for temporary power - yet even this proves insufficient against Crocodile's abilities.
culturalReferences: Egyptian mythology - Chaka represents Anubis as one of Alabasta's guardian deities

themes.description: Crocodile's scheme reaches its peak as even Koza's desperate attempt at peace is sabotaged by Baroque Works agents, showing how thoroughly Crocodile has manipulated the situation.
themes.symbolism: The white flag, traditionally a symbol of peace and surrender, becomes meaningless when shot through by Baroque Works bullets.

themes.description: Despite overwhelming odds and the ticking bomb, Koza and Vivi still attempt to stop the violence, showing the indomitable spirit of those fighting for their homeland.
themes.symbolism: The 25-minute timer represents the literal countdown to Alabasta's destruction.

characterSpotlights.development: Koza finally learns the truth about Crocodile's manipulation and immediately attempts to stop the war, showing his true dedication to Alabasta. His shooting represents his ultimate sacrifice for peace.
keyActions: Raises white flags to stop the rebellion
Shot by Baroque Works agents while proclaiming peace

characterSpotlights.development: Reveals his Devil Fruit powers in a desperate attempt to stop Crocodile. Despite his defeat, he uses his last strength to warn Koza about the bomb.
keyActions: Witnesses the death of the Tsumegeri Guards
Transforms into jackal form for the first time on screen
Defeated but warns Koza about the bomb

characterSpotlights.development: The four guards make their first and final appearance, sacrificing their lives using Hero Water in a futile attempt to defeat Crocodile.
keyActions: Drink Hero Water knowing it will kill them
Attack Crocodile to protect King Cobra
Die from Hero Water's effects after five minutes

characterSpotlights.development: Crocodile's ruthlessness and superiority are on full display as he easily defeats multiple opponents and reveals his complete manipulation of Alabasta's civil war.
keyActions: Refuses to fight the Tsumegeri Guards, letting them die
Watches his bomb timer count down
quotes: I won't bother to fight them since they're going to die anyway.

characterSpotlights.development: Vivi continues her desperate attempts to save her kingdom, revealing the truth to Koza and trying to stop the war through surrender.
keyActions: Reveals Crocodile's true nature to Koza
Commands the royal army to raise white flags

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extends some scenes of the Tsumegeri Guards' attack and their deaths for dramatic effect, while the manga handles it more quickly.
Some dialogue between Vivi, Koza, and Cobra may have been expanded in the anime adaptation.

trivia.fact: This episode covers events from manga Chapters 196 and 197, titled '1' and 'The Leaders' respectively.
Pandaman appears around the 3:30 mark among the palace guards, continuing the series' running joke of the character's cameos.
Hero Water is a concept unique to the Arabasta arc and represents one of the few non-Devil Fruit power enhancements shown in early One Piece, though it comes with fatal consequences.
Chaka's Inu Inu no Mi, Model: Jackal is inspired by Anubis from Egyptian mythology, fitting with Alabasta's Egyptian themes. He and Pell are considered the two guardian deities of Alabasta.
The original Japanese voice actor for King Cobra, Iemasa Kayumi, passed away on September 30, 2014, at the age of 80. He was later replaced by Toshiya Ueda.

sources.title: Iemasa Kayumi, the Japanese Voice Actor for Nefertari Cobra, Passed Away

trivia.fact: This episode originally aired on August 4, 2002 in Japan, but didn't air in the US via 4Kids until May 5, 2007, a gap of nearly 5 years. The Funimation dub aired on March 16, 2010.
